Message.Title: Paypal customer service is the worst
Message.Msg: I made a mistake of entering the wrong bank details by mistake. All I did was enter my checking account as a savings account. So I called them it was the worst experience ever. They said the transaction is pending and all I asked them to do was cancel it because it would never go through according to my bank representative. Paypal said the transaction was pending. Well no DUH. I asked if I could cancel it and he didn't even seem to know. What a nightmare now ill have to wait another few weeks I guess.

Message.Title: New Report: CEOs Massive Salaries Subsidized By Your Taxes
Message.Msg: We always hear about "welfare queens" and poor people gaming the system but don't forget the Mothers Of All Tax Payer Bottle Babies: The Rich. Hey American Sheeple, you're being fleeced. Royally fleeced. The New Robber Barons: How Taxpayers Subsidise CEOs' Multimillion Salaries A new report finds many top executives are taking home more than their corporations pay in taxes – at our expense by Pratap Chatterjee "...Dozens of US CEOs have cashed in on this major tax incentive at an estimated cost to US taxpayers of $9.7bn last year. Statistics provided by National Priorities Project suggest that the same amount of money could have paid for 142,625 elementary school teachers, or healthcare for 4.96 million low-income children. "At a time of austerity, it's beyond absurd that billions of our tax dollars are pouring into executive pockets," says Sarah Anderson, a report co-author. In 1980, the average US CEO was paid 42 times as much as the average worker when tax rates for the richest stood at 70%. Today, that ratio has widened to 380 times – exacerbated in part, no doubt, by the fact that CEOs are able to dramatically reduce their tax burdens by a reduction in top tax rates, as well as several new loopholes introduced in recent years. In fact, some companies paid their CEOs more money than they paid in taxes. Take Aubrey McClendon, CEO of Oklahoma-based Chesapeake Energy, who was paid $17.9m in 2011, while his company gave Uncle Sam just $13m on sales of $11.64bn..." "The Institute for Policy Studies found that 26 of the 100 highest-paid US CEOs took home more in pay than their companies paid in federal income taxes. On average, each of these company bosses was paid $20.4m last year. Another scam that CEOs pull on the taxpayer is called "deferred compensation". The way that works is simple – most taxpayers are expected to pay 35% of their income in taxes the year they earn it. But a CEO does not have to pay the tax until they claim the cash which can be earning interest in the mean time. Depending on how the money is invested, CEOs can engineer a substantial profit. This allowed Michael Duke, CEO of Walmart, to sock away $17,028,615 tax free in 2011, roughly 774 times more than one of his employees would have been allowed to do under normal tax rules. Yet the money these CEOs makes shrinks into insignificance compared to the money that hedge fund managers make. Take Raymond Dalio, who was paid an astronomical $3bn in 2011. This titan of Wall Street had to pay just 15% in taxes because the money was considered "capital gains", as opposed to the average citizen who would be required to pay 25% (in income tax). Cost to the taxpayer in 2011: $450m." http://www.commondreams.org/view/2012/08/20-7

Topic.Title: New Report: CEOs Massive Salaries Subsidized By Your Taxes

Message.Msg: Render unto Ceasar what is Ceasar's.... In my business we give no more than is necessary or desirable. Laws taxing people are put there for a purpose, often not a good one, and laws granting deductions and exemptions are also there for a purpose good or not. This is representative government in action. Go ahead and vote for someone who makes you feel good about keeping your own money. If there are enough of you, things will change. If there are not, you will have to blame your countrymen, not the government. Government is simply the machinery of whoever holds the reins, however tenuously. EAM's article cites some pretty weak examples of loopholes, namely capital consumption allowances (which are incredibly generous in 2011) and deferred compensation. Capital consumption allowance benefits are a Republican idea which President Obama has adopted greatly. These benefits allow companies to write off the cost of certain capital acquisitions immediately or more quickly. Capital-intensive companies such as energy companies benefit tremendously from this program. Deferred compensation is simply somebody electing to be paid their pay in a later year, hardly a loophole in my opinion. JM$.02W

I have done peoples' taxes for 34 years and I know from experience that when it comes to cheating on taxes, there is absolutely no correlation between ideology and compliance. Liberals, conservatives, moderates and apoliticals are honest in equal percentages. Lefty doesn't want to buy bombs; righty doesn't want to pay bums. Cheaters always dress it up in some sociological good, but the bottom line is the bottom line. They want the money for themselves. So heap scorn on Timothy Geithner if you like and I will join you. Taking money from all the downsized, likely to be laid off soon workers, too many without health care, too many who are having trouble making ends meet even WITH two jobs, it's always these folks on the hook when huge banks want paid back for their investement gambles and CEOs want obscene compensation. Topic.Title: New Report: CEOs Massive Salaries Subsidized By Your Taxes

Message.Msg: "what these "loonies" don't understand is that ALL their profit comes from the workers" ---------------- Analmale, you are one naive infantile thinker. When I worked for an employer I was under no illusion that I had any vested interest in the employer's business. We (employees) used to refer to ourselves as whores because essentially the employer used us and dumped us when he was done with us. There was no history, no obligations, no sense of entitlement, we got paid for our hours work and that was the end of it. I once had 36 W2's in one year, I had worked for 36 different employers. The point is, only a communist thinks in the terms that the worker is the greatest member of a society. And you Analmale are a communist if you believe what you wrote above. Communism on paper is the ultimate form of government, the unfortunate fact is that everywhere communism has existed it always ends in disaster. "Workers who pay their taxes, to build roads, schools and all the other day to day infrastructure to make getting rich so possible." Sheer idiocy! Where did the worker get the money to pay taxes? That's right, from a business that made something and sold something. Analhole, when ever did a worker give anybody else a job. JUG EARS postulated the same idiot theory of "you didn't build that", in that one moment JUG EARS exposed the contempt he holds for the American entrepreneur. JUG EARS also espoused his view that the workers should have a stake in all American business like his rape of bond holders when he gave the UAW union a stake in General Motors(pure communism). General Motors is doomed to failure because business is tough enough without an outside interest interfering. Perhaps GM won't fail completely, if JUG EARS gets reelected GM can always get the blueprints for the Trabant to manufacture. If you don't know what t he Trabant car was, it was a communist government produced automobile infamous for horrible quality. It was a two cycle engine, gasoline and oil had to be mixed in the gas tank, the operator's manual said to shake the car to mix the gas before driving after a fill up. That's sounds just like the high functioning idiocy you are purveying here Analmale.

Topic.Title: New Report: CEOs Massive Salaries Subsidized By Your Taxes

Message.Msg: Poor angry Agqut. You DO realize your extreme hate and name calling means you're hardly worth debating with, long ago lost, and it even detracts from the good point or two you actually do make. I am neither a fool nor a liar, and I'm certainly not god#%#%#%#ed. I'm bless baby, blessed. So I don't mind paying my taxes as a business success because I might need a road to drive on, a hospital to go to, I need schools for the rugrats so they do not grow up be illiterate animals that slaughter their elders, like the generation we seem to be raising, many of whom are angry for very good reason. I have no problem with being seen as a "Communist". I'm more like Woddy Guthrie said a "commonest". I'm of the Marx Engels original school, filtered through the Wobblies, the IWW, and has nothing to do with Stalinism. So I clearly know every bit of value in an item comes from nature, handled by the worker, the builder, the craftsman, the designer. CEOs and salesman help, but the world can do without them and probably be much better off. I suffer through the "corporatism" our country (USA) has morphed into, the socialism for only big banks and rich corporations at the expense of everyone else. It hasn't been "democracy" for a very very long time. Just because you think you get to vote for Tweedle Dumb or Tweedle Rich, does not mean this nation has democracy, or much of a future frankly. I manasge to make my living, and plan my future, in spite of that, and on the bones of that. And I'm fine with it. Again, understand only the weak say the things to me you do, and only the weak think they have any affect in doing so. I gather we'd have a far different style of talk in person. Please use the public transportation my tax dollars have created to ride the roads me, and others built, to go to the schools we funded and at least try to expose yourself to the basics of civil discourse. It may do wonders for your mood.
